title: TOP 10 SNOW REMOVAL MISTAKES TRACTOR OWNERS MAKE

tasks.task: Clear snow from driveways and parking lots using tractor-mounted snow pushers; avoid common mistakes.
subtasks: Select appropriate snow pusher material (UHMW, poly, or rubber) to protect paved surfaces.
Properly adjust plow or pusher for maximum efficiency and safety.
Stock necessary sacrificial parts (e.g., sheer bolts) for equipment maintenance.
Use stakes or other markers for reference when plowing curved areas to avoid damaging landscaping.
Plan snow storage locations to prevent overflow throughout the winter season.

tasks.task: Ensure tractor traction and start-up reliability during snow removal.
subtasks: Upgrade tire tread patterns to improve snow navigation.
Distribute ballast or add wheel weights for improved traction.
Check fuel system for seasonal additives to prevent gelation.
Utilize engine block heaters or battery tenders for cold-start assistance.
Familiarize with proper road signaling and lighting procedures while operating snow removal equipment.

tasks.task: Inspect and maintain lights and other equipment before and during winter operations.
subtasks: Replace or repair damaged headlights, tail lamps, and other lighting fixtures.
Consider upgrading to LED bulbs for improved visibility and easier maintenance.
Check glow plugs and other starting aids for functionality in cold temperatures.
